KEYWORDS.TERM: Thirty Years' War, 1618-1648 -- Sources -- Early works to 1800.

DIV1.P: A Coranto. RELATING DIVERS PARTICV∣LARS CONCERNING THE NEWES OVT OF JTALY, Spaine, Turkey, Persia, Bohemia, Sweden, Poland, Austria, the Pallatinates, the Grisons, and diuers places of the Higher and Lower GERMANIE.
Printed for Nathaniel Butter, Nicholas Bourne, and William Shefford, 1622.

DIV1.HEAD: A RELATION OF THIS Weekes newes out of Jtaly, Spaine, Turkey, Persia, Bohemia, and Sweden, Poland, Austria, the Pallatinate, the Hague, and other places of High and Low GERMANY.

DIV2.HEAD: From Rome, Octob. 1. 1622.
DIV2.P: FOr the aduancement of the Ro∣mane Faith, to be preach't a∣mongst the Heathen; there are already one thousand fiue hun∣dred Crownes of yearely pensi∣on, layd vp in seuerall places, for the maintenance of those, who will vndertake to be the Apostles, and goe to conuert the vnbeleeuing Gentiles.
Last Tuesday, the Cardinall Fianardi, dyed of a bur∣ning Feauer; he hath giuen great Legacies to his Bre∣thren and friends.
The Cardinall Ludouisie hath purchased the Duke∣dome of Zaragola, of the Duke of that Place; for 800000. Crownes.

DIV2.HEAD: From Rome, Octob. 7.
DIV2.P: The Archbishop of Spalato, who since his comming out of England, hath resyded at Antwerpe, hath long since submitted himselfe to the Holy, Catholique, and Romane Mother-Church. And therefore, there are fiue thousand Crownes made ouer to him, to defray the charges of his iourney to Rome; the Bils of ex∣change for the taking vp the money, are with him a good while before this, and hee well onwards on his Iourney, that he may receiue his absolution from the Popes holinesse: He hopes well: for whereas before his comming into England, hee had great suits in the Court of Rome, nine yeares together; and the Pope, who was his mortall enemy, was also to be his Iudge; he made vse of England, as of a Whoode, to keepe his head from a storme; but since by the Popes death, the storme is ouer; he comes now abroad againe into the sun-shine; for his Holinesse that now is Bishop of Rome, was sometimes his Schoole-fellow. It is repor∣ted, that he hath made very good vse of England.

DIV2.HEAD: From Rome, the same Date.
DIV2.P: The Bacchieri, (or Banckers) Spinola and Forali, are broken, for some thousands of Crownes.

DIV2.HEAD: From Naples, Octob. 3.
DIV2.P: The Galleyes of Prince Philibert, and those of Bi∣serta are still out at Sea; the Turkish Pyrates, and the Christians, daily lye in waite one for another.

DIV2.HEAD: From Venice, Octob. 5.
DIV2.P: The Collonell Obertrawt, a natiue of the Pallatinate, hauing lyen some time at Zuriche, is come hither to offer his seruice to this State, eyther to goe backe to ayde the Grisons, or to be imployed else-where.

DIV2.HEAD: From Madrill, in Spaine, Octob. 8.
DIV2.P: In the end of September, here dyed that great man of State, who still entertained and dispatcht so many businesses, Don Balthasar de Zuniga: hee was a great man, and Vncle to the Fauourite, the Count de Oliua∣rez. Here will be great misse of him, for his many good seruices: he it was, who was the chiefe Commissio∣ner for our King, in the treaty betweene the French Ambassador, and the Deputies of the Grisons, about the Valtoline, which he concluded to the great benefit of his Country.

DIV2.HEAD: From Madrill the same day.
DIV2.P:
Here is an order giuen out of his Maiesties com∣mand, for a great and generall contribution, to be ta∣ken by the poll; that is, euery one must giue a peece
of eight Reals (which is foure shillings English) to∣wards the warres in Holland, and the charges which his Maiestie hath beene at, for the Valtoline, and his great Nauy, lately set to sea, two or three seuerall wayes.

DIV2.HEAD: From Rome, Octob. 11.
DIV2.P: The Viceroy of Naples hath layd a new Impositi∣on vpon the Corne and Fruits: which would amount to 80000. Crownes a yeare; which should be a trea∣sury to allay any sudden commotions, and to supply the King of Spaines present want of new Coyne: but for that those that were appointed to be the Colle∣ctors, haue refused such a thankelesse office, the Vice∣roy hath sent Post into Spaine, to know the Kings re∣solution therein.

DIV2.HEAD: From Madrill.
DIV2.P: Wee heare for certaine, that the Count de Gondo∣mar, late Ambassador in England, shall returne thither againe the next Spring, but whether as ordinary or extraordinary, is not yet knowne.
The same is confirmed by his owne Letters in Eng∣gland, as some Catholiques say.

DIV2.HEAD: From Prague Septem. 29.
DIV2.P:
The Archisynagoga, or Gouernour of the Iew∣ish Synagogue, who is called Basseri, is lately come
from Vienna, and arriued here, where hee is recei∣ued of his Nation with great honour. For he hauing kept the Iewes true to his Imperiall Maiestie, all the time of these Bohemian troubles (the Iewes better affecting the Catholique Religion, then the refor∣med,) and hauing largely contributed to the warres of the Emperour: his Maiestie hath now rewarded him with a Chayne of Gold, weighing one hundred Ducats, and with his owne picture to hang about his necke, with many other Imperiall gifts, and many fauours also and new priuiledges to his Nati∣on, both for their personall quiet, and the freer ex∣ercise of their Religion. Hee comming neere to this City with fiue Coaches in his trayne, was met vpon the way with diuers Iewes, both on Horse and Foote, who conducted him, with great triumph, (af∣ter their fashion) into the Towne, lodging him in their City. Hee was apparrelled after the Hunga∣rian fashion: His Cloake was of redde Veluet, his Sword and Spurres guilded, and he ware the afore∣said Chayne about his necke, with the Emperours picture hanging at it.

DIV2.HEAD: From Prague, Septem. 27.
DIV2.P:
The execution of the Bohemian Lords, is now bet∣ter knowne to be made, for these reasons; and these men haue beene, and are to be executed: First, those that were present when the other Catholique Lords were thrown out at the window, as they sate in Coun∣cell together, about the putting out of the Empe∣rour,
from being King of Bohemia. Secondly, all those that can be found, to haue beene of confedera∣cie with those that conspired against his Imperiall Maiestie, and the House of Austria. Thirdly, those that were present at the reiection of Ferdinand the Emperour. Fourthly, those that were present at the election of the Elector Fredericke Count Pallatine.

Fiftly, all those that serued in the Campe before Vienna, when that it was blockt vp by the Count Mansfield, or afterward, eyther vnder the Prince of Anholt, the Count Hollocke; or vnder any other his Im∣periall Maiesties Enemies and Traytors: What the Issue of this will be, time will shew.

By this last Article, many of the Inferiour sort of Gentlemen, and the Artificers also, are like to be brought in question, who were Souldiers against the Emperour at his owne doores, and there is much murmuring.

DIV2.HEAD: From Vienna, Octob. 5.
DIV2.P: The Count of Schellenburgh; who is a Moneth since returned out of Turkey, (seeing that the great Turke hath reuealed the conspirators against the Emperour, who solicited him to ayde them; many of whose names are to be seene at their owne Letters, which the great Turke also sent: He hath submitted himselfe and asked pardon of his Maiestie: but was neuerthe∣lesse committed to prison, till hee hath reuealed the rest of them that authorized him, to goe into Turkey, as their Ambassador. Whereupon euery man almost feares himselfe at Prague.

DIV2.HEAD: From Franckford, Octob. 14.
DIV2.P: Here is arriued a Bauarian Commissioner in the name of his Imperiall Maiestie, and his highnesse of Bauaria; his request is; That the Burgomaster of our cittie, would permit him to leauy certaine soul∣diers in our towne and thereabouts, for the Em∣perors seruice. And that they might likewise be maintained at the charge of the Citizens, and be billetted in their houses vntill the generall muster. But the Burgomaster hath excused himselfe, from granting either of these requests. By this we see that the Emperour hath some other emploiment for them, for Monsieur Tilly thinkes himselfe strong enough in the Palatinate; and those that besieged Glatz, haue long since and often refused the aides of some thousands of Cossacks, who offered them their seruice.

DIV2.HEAD: From Franckford, Octob. 16.
DIV2.P:
Although it was written long since that those Cossaks and Crabats which were rambled together about Oppenheim, and had passed the Rhine, being of horse and foot about 7000. besides many wo∣men and children, were to goe towards Silesia, and had already passed on through the Landtgraue of Hessens and Darmstadts countries, and so to the fo∣rest of Oldenwaeldt, where they were to goe for∣wards
(as we then heard) yet it is since knowne that to the great griefe of the country thereabouts, they are there still staid: and for that the Prin∣ces of the Empire are loath to haue so many rude fellowes, passe through their countryes, and for that the Emperour findes by experience of others of their Nation, who went before, how he is like to be troubled with them: it is said that they are to be sent into the low Countries; for that the Spanish armie hath had there no good successe, and is also much weakned in Brabant. Of which last part of the newes, it is said that the Prince, Archbishop Elector of Cullen, had this word also sent to Hanaw, (where he then lay a∣bout October, in his iourney towards the Dyet of Regenspurg) that these Cossacks were very like∣ly to be sent into Brabant, to reenforce the Spa∣nish companies, which are farre more in the List then they are in the Polle.

DIV2.HEAD: From Prague, Octob. 11.
DIV2.P: Those Cossacks which before made towards Silesia, hauing made great spoile in that countrey are now fallen backe againe, with an intent (as it is thought) to thrust themselues into the Prin∣cipality of Glogau.

DIV2.HEAD: From Ladenburg in the Palatinate, Octob. 14.
DIV2.P: The two brothers the Counts of Wiedt, are at great dissention, and daily way-lay one another, so that all the passages hereabouts, are very dan∣gerous to passe; and especially for those merchants who staid late at Franckford Mart, and are to trauell this way.

DIV2.HEAD: From Mentz. Octob. 15.
DIV2.P: There is likely to bee verie good Rhenish wine this Vintage which is now begunne; but it will be verie scant, and exceeding deare.

DIV2.HEAD: Out of the Palatinate.
DIV2.P: From hence we heare the same things confir∣med which we wrote in our former booke prin∣ted Nouember 5. concerning Manheim and Franc∣kendale; which we will not heere repeat, for that we will not abuse you, by selling you one thing twice.

DIV2.HEAD: From Cullen, Octob. 21.
DIV2.P: The plague continueth here very hot, for all the cold weather, there die 800, a weeke in this citie, besides those which die in the townes and villa∣ges hereabouts.

DIV2.HEAD: From Stockholme in Sweden, Septemb. 17.
DIV2.P: The long warres betweene the Kings of Poland and Sweden, are for the present ceased: for there is a truce taken for 10. moneths, of which the King of Sweden hauing before written to his friends, is since this, safely returned to his Castle of Stockholme.

DIV2.HEAD: From Danske, Septemb. 30.
DIV2.P: The King of Poland desired to haue the Parel Church, where the Lutheranes preached before, at his owne disposing, purposing to place a Couent of Friers in it. Their Councell haue met about it, and are to giue an answer within 8. daies.

DIV2.HEAD: From Switz, Octob. 7.
DIV2.P: The Archduke Leopoldus hauing since the Diet of Lindaw, lien very sicke at Rusach, begins now to recouer.

DIV2.HEAD: From the Hage.
DIV2.P:
It was here somewhiles since reported, that the Duke Christian of Brunswicke (he that hath beene that noble Champion and companion in armes with Count Mansfield) with his mother the old
Dutches of Brunswick, haue beene in the end of this summer about leauying some forces for the King of Bohemiaes seruice. But since we heare that there is a more generall agreement, of the Nor∣therne Protestant kings and Princes of Germany; and that the Kings of Denmarke and Sweden, the Duke Elector of Saxonie, and the Marquesse Ele∣ctor of Brandenburgh, the Duke of Brunswick, the Landtgraue of Hessen, and diuers others of their Religion, are about to leauy a common army to re∣estate the Prince Elector Palatine in his countreyes againe: seeing that no forraine armes can doe it so conueniently; and besides the example so much concernes the libertie of Germany, and the estates of the Princes of the Empire, that they beginne to thinke it is not safe for them to suffer a strange soul∣dier to be brought into Germany, which is contra∣ry to the lawes of the Empire in generall, and dan∣gerous to the Princes in particular. The Marquesse of Badens cause also, who for taking part with the King of Bohemiah, is depriued of his upper Mar∣quisate by the Emperours iudgement: is also taken into consideration.

DIV2.HEAD: From Amsterdam, Octob. 31.
DIV2.P:
It is here reported for certaine; That the Prince the Duke of Brunswick, who kept his Court at Wol∣fenbettle in the Land of Brunswick, is lately dead: So that he dying without issue; the Dukedome is fallen to our Noble yong Souldier, Christian of
Brunswick; who hath by this gotten a Dukedome, after the losse of his arme.

DIV2.HEAD: From Constantinople, Septemb. 8.
DIV2.P: The new Grand Signior Sultan Mustapha, pre∣pares mightily for his intended warres against the Persians, and they also, doe all that they can to be ready for him: The Turke hath still (for the most part) beene thus much before hand with the Persi∣an; that hee hath marcht with his Armies to visite him in his owne Countrie, about Tauris or some o∣ther place. If any thing hinder this Expedition, that he goes not now also home to him; it is for that there is a great conspiracie of diuers Bashawes a∣gainst their Emperour, there being an hundred thousand men (as it is said) ready prest by them a∣gainst their Soueraigne. Thus Persia and Turkey (who beare the Sunne and the Moone in their Ban∣ners) are as like now as euer, to eclipse one anothers glory. Some say that this present Sultan hath beene perswaded, to goe visite the Tombe of their Pro∣phet Mahomet, at Meccha: and that hee knowes not handsomely how to returne to Constantinople, but that his simplicitie is by the great Bashawes and Beg∣lerbegs made vse of; that while they may rule all at home, he is sent a Pilgrimage, Meccha being to him little better than an holy prison.

DIV2.HEAD: From Brussels, Octob. 7.
DIV2.P:
Her Highnesse the Archduchesse Infanta, with the rest of her Councell, considering the dishonour
which hereby redounded to the Spanish partie, that after the ill successe of the Armie before Bergen vp Zoome, so many souldiers, euen of the naturall Spa∣niards and Italians, should run from their Colours, and goe serue the States her enemies, or else goe for their owne Countries; thought good for the punish∣ment of those, and the terror of others, that should dare to attempt such an escape; to proscribe some fifteene of them by name, the Copie of which pro∣scription here followeth, translated out of Low Dutch.

OPENER.SIGNED: Isabella Clara Eugenia, by the Grace of God, In∣fanta of Spaine, &c.

DIV1.P:
Whereas wee vnderstand that Stephano Prena Sergeant of a Band: Ioan Paulo Se∣rin, Sergeant: Vasalo Sericho, Corporall: Damiano de Michele: Damiano Lorenzo: Bartholomeo de Ba∣stiano: Lucio San Piero: Bartholomeo Albano: Iosepho Brocola: Siluio Romano: Vincentio Brilia: Nicolao Lombardo: Iacobo Lorano: Giouanni Piolan, and Do∣minico de Valentin; are runne ouer to the Enemie, and haue treated with them vpon matters of trea∣son, against the seruice of his Maiestie: Wee there∣fore declare and pronounce them to be Traytors; and doe giue withall charge to all the Subiects of his Maiestie, and to the Souldiers of his Campe, to hold and take them for such; and that they doe all their best endeuour to kill them and depriue them of their liues. And whosoeuer shall so doe, in what place soeuer he can atchieue it, and shall haue slaine any of them; shall giue notice thereof to the Audi∣tour generall; who shall giue order, that a thousand Philips Dollars shall be paid vnto him for such his
seruice: and moreouer, if he be a Souldier, wee will adnance him, and bestow the command of a Foot∣company vpon him, of those of his owne Nation. Declaring moreouer, that if any of them shall kill or make away one another, ouer and aboue the foresaid recompence, We will pardon him his of∣fence. And to the end that this may come to the knowledge of euery one of them, we haue directed Peter Puteanus, Counceller and Auditor generall of the Campe, that he shall cause this our commande∣ment to be published in this Court, and in such o∣ther places, where it shall seeme most expedient.

CLOSER.DATELINE: Gi∣uen at Bruxels the seuenth of October 1622.
CLOSER.SIGNED: By her Highnesse order, Matheo de Vrquina.

POSTSCRIPT.P: Imprinted at Bruxels, by Hubrecht Anthoon, sworne Booke-Printer of the Court, 1622.

DIV2.P: The Copie of this Proclamation, the Hollanders haue also gotten and Imprinted; prefixing also a long Discourse, the Summe whereof is this. That this deuice was taken for no other end, then by na∣ming but fifteene only, to make the Boores of their owne Countrey beleeue, that there were no more that came away: whereas the Iournals of Berghen affirme, that they came running by ten, twentie, thirty or more at a time, out of the Campe, into the Towne.

DIV2.HEAD: From Middleborough, Octob. 22.
DIV2.P: NOt long before the Campe of the Prince of O∣range brake vp from Rossendale, the Marquesse Spinola sent a Trumpet to the Prince, with the Ritt∣master, (Captaine of a horse troope) Abremon, to treat about keeping faire quarter on both sides; whereas before there had beene some violent disor∣ders committed on both parties, against the Law of Armes. Whereupon 15. committees were appoin∣ted for each side, who met together at a village cal∣led Calmpthout betweene Bergen vp Zoome, and Ant∣werpe: on our side, there went among others, the Baron of Sterkenburgh, and the noble Drossard Bro∣chum. At first they could not well agree, so that they were ready to depart: but at last the matter was brought to this point, That an Earle being taken Prisoner should pay for his ransome 10000. Gilders, a Campemaster 1000. a Captaine 600. a Leifetenant 150. an Ancient, Sergeant, horseman and foot sol∣dier, each accordinglie to his pay. Thus was it con∣cluded at Calmpthout, October 16. 1622. and with this the Committees returned to their Quarters.

DIV2.HEAD: From Amsterdam, October 27.
DIV2.P:
THE Spanish Forces lie still about the villages of Brabant, and some of them haue been seen about Venlo in Gelderland, which passe there ouer the
bridge, and it was said that more should follow them, but we haue heard no more of them, or that they en∣tended any thing else, then to reenforce their Garri∣sons, and especially to strengthen the towne of Goch.

DIV2.HEAD: From Rossendale, October 19.
DIV2.P: THE 15. of this moneth, there went some horse∣men from hence, who fell vpon a Convoy of the enemies, consisting of 3. troope of horse, whereof they killed one of the Captaines, whose dead body with 27. prisoners they brought away with them, the which day there went out a party of 80. of our horsemen to Herentall, and passed through 180. of the enemies horse, and tooke 80. of them prisoners, and brought away 33. of them, the rest ransomed themselues. There was the best horse of Grobben∣donces troope, called the Gens, taken, they haue got∣ten 162. Gilders by the sale of these horses.

The 17. day there were there sold 58. of the Ene∣mies horse, with saddles, bridles, and pistols, which were brought from little Brabant. These exploits wee giue you vpon the credit of their owne Lowe Dutch newes.

DIV2.HEAD: From Bergen vp Zoome.
DIV2.P: THE Count Mansfields Souldiers haue catcht the bootehalers which were sent out by the Consta∣ble of Hertochen Bosche.

Our Soldiers haue beene nere the towne of Lyer, and haue taken good prize and prisoners, and a∣mongst the rest, there was one old cruell man, called
Schapaetien, who had before caused many of our sol∣diers to be shot to death when they were taken pri∣soners: this fellow was by our men serued likewise. And these things the Hollanders tell of the actions of their owne men, but impart nothing that should make for the honor of any of Spinolaes, of whose do∣ings, they suffer vs to knowe little.

DIV2.HEAD: The order and raising of the Prince of Orenges Campe from Rossendale.
DIV2.P: THE order of the Rising was this; There being many ships and boats in a readinesse to attend: There was first shipt the greatest peices of Cannon, and his Excellency with the small peeces of Cannon and some falconets marched towards Oudenbergh, many hundreds of ships being there in a readinesse, where one part of our foot went aboard. In the meane time our horse stood ranged in battell array, vntill the foot were shipt. After this, his Excellencie being accompanied with many Noblemen, Lords, Rittmasters, Captaines and other Cavalliers, mar∣ched to Breda: where hauing put all things in order, the most part of our Cavalliery with his Excellency, and Prince Henry Van Nassaw, and Count Ernestus of Nassaw, besides many other Noblemen and braue Warriours, with the soldiers of Count Mansfield, were by his Excellency sent higher vpwards, and their Rendezvous was at St. Grauenwert, from whence it was thought, that the horse might well and safely march, as far as into the Bishopricke of Cullen, and keepe house there so ratime

The Campe rose vpon Fryday, and the Wednes∣day after, the Prince of Orange returned to the Hagh, being brauely receiued by the foure companyes of Townesmen. This intelligence although it came something late to our hands, yet we here giue you it, for that it is a good orderly one, and relates many particulars.

DIV2.HEAD: From Amsterdam, October 31.
DIV2.P: THe Horsemen of the States one day amongst the rest, brought in a booty valued at 6000. pound sterling: which made many of their fingers itch, to be doing with the Spaniards also: But his Excellency saith; that hee will beat them well enough, with ly∣ing still.
The King of Bohemia is safe returned to the Hagh, and the Duke of Brunswicke, and Count Mansfield, tooke vp Souldiers for Westphalia. The States also take vp Souldiers, for all it is towards winter.

DIV2.HEAD: From Berghen and Middleberough.
DIV2.P:
THe Marquesse of Baden was arriued at the Hagh, before his Excellency came thither; and so like∣wise was the King of Bohemia, and the Count Mans∣field, hauing consulted with the King of Bohemia, a∣bout some important businesse, and knowing that his Souldiers were already marcht vpwards, tooke his leaue of his Maiesty and the Queene, and went with all speed, together with the Marquesse of Ba∣den, to the place where his Souldiers lay: and vnder∣standing
of some disorders committed by some of them, he punisht them with the Strappado, and other bodily punishments. Hee is since this marcht vp∣wards.

DIV2.HEAD: From Rossendale, October 23.
DIV2.P: AFter all this, the Lords the States looking as well to the businesse of the Spanish Fleete, as they haue done to their Land Armie, haue taken vp al the ships (Merchants and others) that are fit to beare Ordnance, for their seruice. And for the speeding of their fleete which they haue put out to sea, they write from Amsterdam, Octob. 31. That the ships of Holland haue lately fought with 5. Spanish Car∣ricks, (being of those that went to Argire,) and beat them.

In London also the newes is from Plimmoth, that in the end of October, The Hollanders hauing 50. sayle of ships about these Seas, haue lately fought with some of the Spanish Fleete; and with their shot so rack't through one galleon, that she being no longer able to liue at Sea, put into harbour at Plimmouth, which she had much adoe to recouer without sinck∣ing: and what worke the rest of the two Feets made one with another, we haue not yet heard off.

DIV2.HEAD: From Amsterdam, October, 20.
DIV2.P: VVEE heare also from sundry places, That the Hollanders haue taken away the Barrels and o∣ther Seamarkes, that the Spanish Fleete may haue no direction to find their hauens, if they should offer to fall in with any of their coasts.

But now for the maintenance of this Land Army and great Fleete at Sea, they haue taken the same course, that the King of Spaine hath done in his do∣minions, That is, they haue laid a generall Taxati∣on by the polle: for man, woman and child is to giue a Gilder (that is 2. shillings English,) and the 500 pennie besides of his goods: so that he that is worth 500. pound, is to giue 20 shillings towards the wars, which will amount to an inestimable summe of mo∣ney, for women, children, seruants and all must pay it. Yea the very poore that receiue Almes also, for whom the Collectors must pay it, as it is said.

DIV2.HEAD: From Middlebrough, Octob. 26.
DIV2.P:
THE 20. of this month, there happened a most lamentable accident, by shipping one Oxehead, and two Firkins of Gunpowder, and yet no certain∣tie can be had how it tooke fire: but so it is, that the fire taking it, as it lay vpon the keye side, ready to be caried a ship-board: It gaue such a cracke: that on both sides of the hauen, almost all the tyles of the houses, and the glasse-windowes, were shaken down, and many things within the houses also, throwne
downe and broken. Besides all this, some men, wo∣men and chlidren were blowne vp into the aire; so that in some places farre and neere from thence, was found here an Arme, & there a Leg, here one head, and there another, and in other places, hands, feete, Armes, Hearts, Gutts, Liuers, and other parts of mens bodies; and by it a man burnt to death. In fine, this was such a lamentable spectacle to behold, and so fearefull, that it cannot be well expressed, It is a memorable warning to euery man that is to deale with this damnable Gun powder, to looke to it well and warilie.

Doctor Conradus Vorstius, a subtile Logician and Philosopher, one of the Fathers and broachers of Arminianisme, being Professor of Diuinity in the schoole of Steinfurt, is lately deceased at Connighen.
